questions.question: You click a link in an email that redirects to a site with a slightly misspelled domain name (e.g., g00gle.com).
questions.explanation: This is likely a phishing site using typosquatting to trick users.

questions.question: You upload a sensitive file to a public Google Drive folder without setting permissions.
questions.explanation: Public folders can be indexed or accessed by anyone with the link.

questions.question: You receive a phone call from someone claiming to be IT support asking for your password to 'verify your account.'
questions.explanation: No legitimate support will ever ask for your password. This is social engineering.

questions.question: You use an outdated version of a plugin on your personal website.
questions.explanation: Outdated plugins often contain known vulnerabilities attackers can exploit.

questions.question: You connect your personal laptop to your workplace network without informing IT.
questions.explanation: Unmanaged personal devices can introduce security risks to corporate networks.

questions.question: You encrypt sensitive files before storing them on a cloud drive.
questions.explanation: Encrypting files ensures confidentiality even if the cloud account is breached.

questions.question: You use fingerprint authentication on your phone instead of a 4-digit PIN.
questions.explanation: Biometric authentication is generally more secure than short PINs.

questions.question: You leave your work laptop unlocked while stepping away for a few minutes at a café.
questions.explanation: Unattended, unlocked devices are vulnerable to theft or tampering.

questions.question: You receive an unexpected USB stick in the mail with a label 'Company Confidential' and plug it in out of curiosity.
questions.explanation: USB drives can carry malware. Never use untrusted devices.

questions.question: You use email filters to automatically archive messages from unknown senders.
questions.explanation: This may hide phishing attempts. Always review unknown messages cautiously.

questions.question: You install antivirus software but never update it.
questions.explanation: Outdated antivirus can’t detect the latest threats.

questions.question: You regularly back up your files to an external hard drive you disconnect afterward.
questions.explanation: Offline backups protect against ransomware and accidental deletion.

questions.question: You see a browser popup that says 'Your computer is infected! Click here to clean it now!' and you follow it.
questions.explanation: Fake popups are a common method to spread malware.

questions.question: You use incognito mode to stay completely anonymous online.
questions.explanation: Incognito prevents local tracking but not network-level monitoring or website tracking.

questions.question: You use a website that doesn't have HTTPS but still enter your login credentials.
questions.explanation: Without HTTPS, your data can be intercepted.

questions.question: You receive a text message with a link claiming your delivery failed and needs rescheduling.
questions.explanation: These are often smishing attacks. Verify through the official website instead.

questions.question: You install a new app and review its permissions before granting access.
questions.explanation: Reviewing app permissions helps avoid unnecessary or malicious access.

questions.question: You use a personal email address to manage admin rights for your company's server.
questions.explanation: Use dedicated, monitored accounts for admin tasks — not personal ones.

questions.question: You receive a security warning in your browser when visiting a site, but proceed anyway because you trust it.
questions.explanation: Security warnings indicate potential danger — never ignore them without verifying.

questions.question: You download free software from a third-party site because the official site requires registration.
questions.explanation: Unofficial sources can host tampered or malicious versions of software.
